svcsubproc.title: Mounting Angles
svcsubproc.para: The use of mounting angles to mount the fifth wheel to the vehicle frame is recommended . Mounting angles provide for more direct transfer of the load to the frame sidemembers for better stress distribution. Some fifth wheels incorporate integral mounting angles as part of the fifth wheel assembly.

Mounting angles must be made of steel conforming to SAE J410, grade 965X, 0.312 inch (8 mm) thick; or ASTM A572, grade 50, 0.38 inch (.6 mm) thick; or conform to fifth wheel manufacturer's specifications that cover your particular circumstances.

It is permissible to cut mounting angles to provide clearance for spring mounting brackets, etc. Cutouts in the vertical flanges of the mounting angles should be minimized in number and size. Cutouts must be rounded at the inside corners. Inner radii of cutouts should be 0.5 inch (13 mm) minimum; 0.75 inch (19.0 mm) radii are preferred.
To make cutouts in mounting angles, drill holes at radii of cutouts . Then, saw or torch cut to remove remaining material. Cut edges should be ground smooth.

Some vehicles have spring mounting brackets designed to permit installation of fifth wheel mounting angle between the spring bracket and vehicle frame . Remove factory installed spacers to install mounting angles. Re-tighten bolts as specified in the Torque Chart.
Mounting angles should be secured to frame sidemembers using quantity and spacing of bolts as determined by following the guidelines provided in this section.

svcsubproc.title: Mounting Bolts
svcsubproc.para: The use of phosphate and oil coated SAE Grade 8 flanged fasteners is recommended. Where flanged fasteners are not available, the use of hardened steel flat washers under bolt head and nut is recommended.
Where locations of mounting bolts are limited by cutouts, the new bolt pattern should conform as closely as possible to recommendations in terms of number of fasteners, edge distances and spacings.
For horizontal bolt applications (mounting angle-to-frame sidemember), use 0.625- inch (16 mm) diameter bolts. Tighten nuts as specified in the Torque Chart.

For vertical bolt applications (fifth wheel-to-mounting angle, fifth wheel-to-support plate, fifth wheel-to-cross tie, cross tie-to-mounting angle), use 3/4-inch (19 mm) diameter bolts. These bolts must be flanged head or hex head with hardened flat washers. Tighten nuts as specified in Torque Chart.

note.para: Some sliding and fixed fifth wheels are designed to use 0.625-inch (16 mm) diameter vertical bolts. These are acceptable where specified by design.

svcsubproc.para: Care must be taken to prevent fretting (chafing) damage to frame top flange by sharp edges on fifth wheel mounting parts. The Figure below illustrates methods of preventing fretting (chafing) damage at leading and trailing edges. These methods include:

step1.para: Chamfering the edges of fifth wheel mounting parts contacting frame top flange.
Use of a "flex-lip" to gradually diminish contact forces.

figure.caption: Figure 29. Methods of Preventing Fretting Damage

svcsubproc.para: Fifth wheel and mounting parts should be positioned on the vehicle frame to provide maximum contact between the parts which transfer the vertical load onto the upper flange of the frame. Clamp to assure contact before tightening bolts.

svcsubproc.title: Fixed (Non-Sliding) Fifth Wheels
svcsubproc.para: Typical installations of fixed (non-sliding) fifth wheels are illustrated in Figure 30, Figure 31, Figure 32, Figure 33, Figure 34 and Figure 35.
Mounting angles should be secured to frame sidemembers with a minimum of five bolts per side with bolt spacing as shown in Figure 30.
Recommended fixed fifth wheel mounting dimension limits are shown in Figure 30. These limits are as follows:

figure.caption: Figure 30. Fixed Fifth Wheel Mounting Dimension Limits (Typical)

svcsubproc.para: Dimension "A" (Trunnion centerline spacing) 29 to 34 inches (736 to 863 mm).
Dimension "B" (Fifth wheel offset with respect to rear axle or tandem rear axle centerline) 0 to 24 inches (0 to 609 mm).
Dimension "C" (Fifth wheel pivot height above frame) 6 inches (152.4 mm) maximum.
Be sure to refer to the segments in this section for mounting angle and cutout information, bolt sizes and torque specifications and corrosion protection on aluminum frames.

warning.para: Failure to follow the recommended procedures in this section may result in damage to the vehicle frame and possible injury to the operator.

svcsubproc.para: For vehicle frame assemblies without bogie gussets or "C" channel frame reinforcements, install a set of flat cross ties as shown in Figure 31 and Figure 32.
For bolted base type fifth wheels, bolt the cross ties and spacers as shown in Figure 31. For fifth wheels with integral mounting angle, weld the cross ties as shown in Figure 32.
Cross ties should be a minimum of 0.31 inch (8.0 mm) thick x 5 inches (127 mm) wide. Recommended material is 0.31 inch (8.0 mm) thick HSLA 80,000 PSI yield material (SAE 980X).

For bolted base type fifth wheels, a single flat plate or a corrugated plate can be used instead of cross ties. The flat plate should have the bolt pattern shown in Figure 33 (top view). The corrugated plate should be installed as shown in Figure 33.

For vehicle frame assemblies which have bogie gussets (such as a typical Hendrickson suspension) many fifth wheel installations may be made without cross ties as shown in Figure 34 and Figure 35. Cross ties may be required in some cases, as indicated.

svcsubproc.title: Sliding Fifth Wheels
svcsubproc.para: These guidelines apply to sliding fifth wheel assemblies where the rails or tracks are tied together on a mounting plate or with cross ties.
A typical installation of a sliding fifth wheel is illustrated in the Figure below.

Mounting angles should be secured to frame sidemembers with bolts, the minimum number of which are to be determined by dividing the distance between the front and rear bolt holes, as shown in Figure 36, by 7.0 inches (177.8 mm) and adding 1.
Recommended sliding fifth wheel mounting dimension limits are as follows:
Dimension "B" (Fifth wheel offset with respect to bogie centerline) 0 to 36 inches (0 to 914 mm) maximum.
Dimension "C" (Fifth wheel pivot height above frame) 6.0 inches (152.4 mm) maximum.

Sliding fifth wheels, because of their length and construction techniques, are prone to warping and misalignment. This along with vehicle frame variations makes it necessary to check and correct for proper fit where needed.
